‘You’re familiar, of course, with Alex Thorley?’ You ask, your fingers lightly dancing around the outer rim of a spit-polished glencairn. These were the first words you'd exchanged with the man sat opposite you since you first arrived roughly thirteen seconds ago. Between yourself and the man was a lacquered desk – upon which – rested a series of manilla folders. His eyes pore across the folder and you continue observing the man’s tumefied face for any betrayal of cognitive awareness.

‘No,’ the man replies as he hastily reaches for the first folder with grubby fingers. ‘Is he one of yours?’

‘They,’ you reply in turn, slapping his sausage-like appendages away from the folder. ‘And no, they are not.’

The grotesque man nurses his fingers between cupped hands. His muttered complaints are inaudible beneath the din of halogen bulbs buzzing faintly within the cramped office. Above your heads, a large fan circulates frigid air around the office with a constant whirring and whining. Whir-whine; whine-whir.

‘One of mine?’

‘Again, no.’ You smile as you sip at the whiskey provided by the bloated man — it tastes like bitter regrets. The man's glassy, pale eyes blink like some gigantic confused frog. You watch as blood rushes beneath the surface of his flabby face.

‘Then why would I ever be familiar with them!’ He shouts, his fingers briefly curled into grubby fists gripping at the table's lip.

You offer an apologetic shrug and your kindest smile. ‘Just thought you might have been is all.’

‘Well then, how might I help you with this Thorley? Were they involved in some kind of altercation?’ The odoriferous beast smiles thinly — visibly struggling to conceal his apparent frustration with you.

‘Oh no, nothing like that.’ You reply as a smirk slowly begins to grow across your lips. An inside joke takes seed within your mind and you can't help but stifle a laugh. ‘It's a rather big story.’

‘Are you insulting me?’ The large man pauses for a brief moment, before gathering his composure and licking his crusted lips. ‘I feel as though I'm the butt of some cosmic practical joke. Here you are, rudely barging into my office with serious allegations regarding the conduct of an employee who I don't even recognise!

He pauses again, sipping at his own glass of whiskey and smiling thinly at you. ‘Now, please try and be reasonable with me, whatever did this Alex Thorley do to cause you such grave concerns?’

‘I heard it all started with a burger.’

The rotund ogre cries out with rage – standing up from his desk with some visible effort – before reaching for the nearest object and sending it flying over your shoulder. The glass figurine of a horse lays shatters upon the carpeted floor behind you.

‘My mistake, it was a bagel.’



Act II, Scene 13.

Department of Unreality, interior-exterior-betweenerior. — dusk, complacency.




ALEX THORLEY continues idly tapping away at the keyboard, their fingers brushing against cheap plastic keys the colour of… beige?1

ALEX THORLEY
I’m just going through the motions. That’s all.

ALEX THORLEY continues tapping away at the keyboard. The cheap plastic keys have worn away. There are no letters; only faint impressions. An inordinate amount of time passes. There are no burgers, no bagels, not even sushi — just ALEX THORLEY and a keyboard.2

ALEX THORLEY
I could have this finished tonight if I tried.

ALEX THORLEY continues tapping away at the keyboard. Each fingerstroke compresses and decompresses the spring. Letters shuffle across the piece of paper before them.3

ALEX THORLEY
Or the night before.

ALEX THORLEY sighs as they continue typing, each stroke of their fingers leaving a smudge upon the keys. Even if they were to delete everything upon the page, the smudges would remain and that's something.4

ALEX THORLEY
I’m hungry.

ALEX THORLEY stands up from the desk and peels their fingers away from the keyboard. In the absence of ALEX THORLEY, all that remains upon the keyboard is a sweaty patina of fingerprints.



Act II, Scene 512.

Department of Unreality, interior-exterior-betweenerior. — night, wisenheimer.




ALEX THORLEY continues idly tapping away at the keyboard, their fingers brushing against cheap, yellowed plastic keys.5

ALEX THORLEY
“Nothing upon nothing upon nothing.”

ALEX THORLEY looks at the piece of paper before them. There's more letters upon it now than ever before. Not all of them are good; some of them might even be described as bad — worse, some of them might be described as pointless. If ALEX THORLEY squints, they might be described as words.6

ALEX THORLEY
I'm not asleep, am I?

ALEX THORLEY turns around and looks over their shoulder. A sea of endless office cubicles surrounds their own cubicle; an island all to their lonesome. Sounds of endless, repeated keystrokes fill their ears, but ALEX THORLEY is all alone.7

ALEX THORLEY
I'm hungry again.

ALEX THORLEY reaches into the desk's compartment. It is cold, dark, and damp. Their hand brushes against something, but comes away covered in dust. There is no point to exploring the rest of the desk. ALEX THORLEY closes the compartment and sighs dejectedly.8

ALEX THORLEY
Why am I always hungry?

ALEX THORLEY receives nothing but silence in answer. To feel alone is natural, and natural things are comforting. But to know that you are alone – truly alone – is a discomforting, terrifying sensation. In this moment, ALEX THORLEY knows they are alone. They pick up the keyboard, balancing it between their two hands, before bringing it down across their knee. It snaps.



Act II, Scene 1276.

Department of Unreality, interior-exterior-betweenerior. — morning, satisfactory.




ALEX THORLEY is no longer tapping away at the keyboard. Instead their fingers idly dance upon the surface of the desk. They flick through the manilla folders in their desk's compartment. They are organised alphabetically and none of them are marked by red lines. Instinct or habit, ALEX THORLEY is unsure, but what they are sure of is that ALEX THORLEY had nothing left to do.

ALEX THORLEY
And—

ALEX THORLEY sighs in relief. They stand up from their desk and pace around the office cubicle. The first lap takes thirteen seconds. By the twenty-fifth lap, it only takes them four. They smile and lie down on the floor. Exhaustion floods through their mind. There is nothing. Their consciousness focuses upon the darkness. ALEX THORLEY has nothing left to do.

ALEX THORLEY
—I'm done.

ALEX THORLEY stands up and looks around their office for a moment. A halogen light buzzes somewhere in the distance. The sound of rapid keystrokes slowly fades into the tones of piano keys being struck. A scent of manilla folders wafts through the room. ALEX THORLEY still had nothing left to do.

ALEX THORLEY
I don't feel hungry today.

ALEX THORLEY exits stage left.

Footnotes
1. Beige? Thorley clearly meant manilla. How could that hideous colour have ever been considered the vogue for interior decorating?
2. There are other things aside from Thorley and a keyboard in this place, but they’re relatively unimportant in the here and now. You’ll see.
3. Thorley wouldn't have been finished tonight. If they had been able to be finished by tonight, they would have been finished by tonight.
4. Thorley wouldn't have been finished the night before. Again, if they had been able to be finished the night before, they would have been finished the night before.
5. Better, though how that colour ever became associated with interior design is a mystery to us all.
6. Thorley, of course, knows better than to listen to the solipsistic delusions of a dreaming unconsciousness. Their design is but a pale shade of another.
7. Thorley isn't alone – but then they don't know this – do they?
8. Their work continues.

glen-and-glenda.raw_content:
Glen slowly awakens from his death-like sleep. The sounds of cars beeping as they drive across the motorway pierce his mind, and as he rolls to his side he sees the first tentative beams of sunlight illuminate his bedroom. Small hints of character hang here- a few posters, “The Rounder’s Parade,” an action movie with heavy anti-authoritarian overtones, a couple bookshelves bolted to the wall, and stacks upon stacks of design documents. Many of these have been extracted from the Wanderer’s Library, but a few have been extracted through other means. A few sit in plastic bags, the blood soaking their pages prevented from affecting the other piles of literature.

He stands up, taking off the thin blanket and falling out of bed onto the floor. This is a tried and true method to awaken himself. His head knocks against the bedside drawer, and the receiver of the rifle falls against him, tumbling out of the protective case. Instinctively he cradles the receiver, unaware of what he is doing until his fingers embrace the wooden stock, and he awakens himself from an odd thought process he didn’t understand in the first place.

For an experiment…

He gently plugs the neural jack in, connecting his mind with the… thing inside the receiver.

I am not a thing.

Yes, but what are you?

Why do I need to answer this? Let me go back to sleep.

You sleep?

Glen stares at the wall, their eyes scanning the window in a regular habit. Outside, a massive circle, with three arrows pointing towards a pentagram with line-art depictions of the world map, looms.

The new world order…

Glen, unplug me. Charge me, dipshit.

How did you learn dipshit?

Magic. I am an evolving consciousness- go read my instruction manual.

Glen shrugs, unplugging the nueral connector jack and carefully inserting the charging cord. He stretches, and exits the room, their sunken nonchalantly observing the barenss of their kitchen. He shrugs, and encases himself in the fabrics of civilization. His clothing is “normal.” In what remains of winter, he shields himself with a heavy metal sweatshirt, faded jeans, and Converse shoes of an age incomprehensible to fashionistas. Locking each possible point of entry window, doors, attic and leaves.

The world has changed, and Glen just lives in it. The Three Arrowed Star overlooks all of them, plastered on posters, advertisements, and billboards. They have simply unleashed themselves from the shadows, showing the tentacles they have emplaced across the entire globe. It took a few years, but some sort of global hierarchy has been established- or has already been established. Glen stares at the massive flag being unfolded across the Luxor, a main point of contact for the Undervegas realm.

Fascist? Bastards? Who knows what to name them.

Glen grins to themselves as people stare at the jet-black uniforms, the branded soldiers staring across the causeway. He knows many of them are undergoing an extreme shift of perspective, an extreme destruction of what they thought was a well-collected set of facts about reality. A living gun is just another oddity in this new world, the world of 1999, the world of global communications.

I wonder what 2000 will being.

Glen shrugs, avoiding the main congestion of humanity and snagging a few large cloth bags worth of groceries and returning home, their eyes beginning to twitch from the constant human contact. They shut the door to their home, unleashing a deep breath and returning to the embrace of their kitchen. They begin to cook themselves a breakfast- onions sauteeing, sausage soaking in garlic-filled oil, and broccolli roasted overtop all of it. He sits down at his homemade dinner table, then stands up again, picking up the now fully charged receiver and inserting the neural jack.

You feeling better?

Yes. Some of my mind shuts down when I get a low battery. Please plug me in overnight- it won’t ruin my battery.

I will do just that.

He puts the receiver down, gently running their hand along the pull-bolt and empty magazine slot.

Are we… eating breakfast?

Yes.

Glen begins ea0ting, allowing the food to flow across their taste buds. He savors the spices of the sausage, feeling the slight crunch of the sautéed onions, and the broccoli adds a wonderful salty taste from all the spices it absorbed from the stir fry.

Glen, this is delicious.

Ha, I figured. I was curious if you could contact that part of my body.

Glen, I can contact all of your body.

He raises an eyebrow.

Yes, even that one.

Glen grins, unplugs the receiver, and receives the instruction manual he received from the arms dealer. As the sun slowly arcs across the sky, he reads through the entire thing, Glenda sitting on the dining room table, occasionally squirming in the protein solution. As Glen finishes the manual, he reaches under his sink to retrieve a mini-screwdriver, delicately unplugging the wooden stock and receiver from the brain-tank, isolating it from the rest of the firing mechanisms. He plugs the jacks in again, his vision blurring slightly.

Can you do targeting without the gun?

Perhaps.

Glen stands up, ripping a piece of paper from the instruction manual and balling it up. An arc appears, the paper clump highlighted in a dull orange. The trashcan lid is encircled in a dark red, and a small trace line covers his vision. With practiced movements he has no experience with, his hand arcs forward, a perfect amount of force propelling the clump into the trashcan with a satisfying thwap.

Yes, you can. Interesting.

My capabilities are evolving in real-time. Must be how much of your mind I have access to.

Exactly.

Cradling the brain-tank, Glen goes to his room and receives a few pieces of leather strapping, disused from military days. He expertly ties a few hitches around the tank, ensuring its safety. He puts the strap around his shoulder, and tucks the tank against his upper chest.

What are you doing, Glen?

Had an idea.

Glen leaves the house, embraced by the crowds that come with rush hour traffic. His eyes are shaded by high-density polarized shades, the bright lights of Vegas shimmering against the dark black glass. Snug against his chest, his vision is filled with the bright and angry lights that have invaded almost all of Vegas and the surrounding area.

———

Deep in the cavernous yawning void that is the suburbs surrounding the gambling houses and brothels of Vegas proper, Glen wanders, Glenda clutched tightly against their side and disguised by a billowing pleather cloak. Walking through the dilapidated city streets, with smaller casinos struck by the illness of bankruptcy full of renegades and malcontents, he wanders with direction. Slowly he circulates through the alleyways and tunnels, distributing coin to those in dire need and those in simple need. Before he reaches his destination he will have distributed two hundred dollars in change and bills.

I did not take you for a charitable type, Glen.

This is where I put all my disposable income. It has a better return than stocks, I think.

A man stumbles out of the shadows, their sideways grin punctured by missing teeth and frazzled hair that shakes with each step.

“Glen! My man! How goes it?” A grimy hand is extended, and Glen takes it willingly, returning the strong and solid grip with one of his own. Within the palm is a small money clip with a thousand in cash folded neatly. Both men nod as the clip is slipped into the inside pocket of the man’s tattered coat.

“Arturo. How goes it?”

The man shrugs his shoulders, looking around with derision. “As it always goes in these circumstances, my friend.

How can he be happy in these circumstances?

Shush, you distr”-act me.”

“Glen? How am I distracting?”

“Not you, Arturo, uh, someone else I was thinking of.”

Am I distracting?

“Arturo, do you have any leads?”

“Straight to the point, eh? Yeah, I do- Avelon Boulevard, apartment 4E. Code phrase is slaloming salmon sandwich.”

Glen nods, slapping hands with Arturo again, a small piece of paper with the address exchanged. “Don’t ever change, Arty.”

Arturo winks, shoving the faded bills into their pocket and walking away, their head turning and scanning the crowd. His scent leaves with him, allowing Glen to breath through his nose.

He’s an interesting man. I wonder what his inner life is like.

Boring. Or extremely exciting.

Glen begins to wander again, walking slowly through the neighborhood, walking with seemingly random steps. The surroundings slowly change, from run-down apartment buildings to somewhat dilapidated warehouses to barely kempt storefronts, harsh xenon lights illuminating product. Glen scans them, eyes uncommitingly making contact with so many artifices of capitalism, their folds and cheaply manufactured pieces naught but dust to his eyes. Suddenly, his feet stumble as he passes a dress shop, bright pink pastels and neon colorations assaulting his eyes.

Don’t do that!

I like the colors.

Glen hesitates, staring at the assortment of dresses and shoes, then looking down at his own body. The muscles that he can flex at will, the abdominals cut like canyons, pectorals and shoulders moulded to shoot, forearms blasted by repetitions at the gym. He looks up again, a picture of him wearing a dress and the receiver plastered across his chest in bra flashing across his mind’s eye.

We can choose one after we get the job.

Thank you.

Glen nods, continuing on his way. In front of him a patrol rounds the corner, gray- and pink-colored combat armor masking their aggressive mentality. He sneaks into the closest alley, waiting for them patiently to pass, then emerges back onto the street, a small bead of sweat dripping down his brow. He now has more than enough reason to avoid the bead-headed men and women, the piece of tech strapped across their helmet programmed to detect any kind of anomalous activity.

I feel this does not need to be said, but I would prefer not to be taken and dissected.

I will never let that happen to you, Glenda.

Promises, promises, baby.

Glen grins, finally arriving at the singular apartment complex located on Avelon Avenue. He goes to the entryway, a small glass enclosure with iron bars over the glass, and finds the button labelled 4E, pressing it down. A wiry, nebish voice answers, emanating sweat.

“Who is it?”

“Delivery. Someone ordered a slaloming salmon sandwich?”

A beat of silence passes. Crumpling of papers is heard over the microphone. The door unlocks, a harsh ringing buzz coming from the alarm system. Quickly and succinctly, Glen enters the apartment and climbs his way to the apartment door, passing through hallways with peeling paisley paint and utterly horrid upholstery, their eyes slowly scanning the door with “4E” in faded fake bronze numbering.

Seems safe.

Thank you for your experienced diagnosis.

Glen knocks, once, twice, and thrice, rapping their knuckles against the cheap pine wood, then slowly moves their frame away from the door. It opens, a face that most looks liek an attorney sticking itself out of the partially open frame.

“You here for the- Glen?”

Glen lets loose a thousand lumen smile at the sight of their oldest friend, rushing forward to embrace them, returned in kind with more than a bit of back-patting.

“Glen!”

“Alan! How’s it going?”

The two break apart, Alan’s hands lingering on the tank strapped to Glen’s side.

“Glen? You have some kind of medical disability or some shit?”

Glen scoffs, moving the folds of their clothing aside to show the tank, the brain stem wriggling in greeting.

“I’m uh… training my targeting A.I. It’s been an interesting process.”

Alan shrugs, waving their prosthetic hand to indicate his acceptance of Glen’s entrance into the room. “Come, come, I was hoping I’d pick you up.”

Glen enters the dilapidated apartment, the threadbare furniture and spartan decorations- excepting the pure blizzard of documentation covering the small coffee table and settee.

“This one is a bit of a doozy.”

“Oh really? I couldn’t even tell.”

“Glen, you’ve always been terrible with sarcasm.”

I agree.

“Shut up.”

“What? I didn’t mean it, Glen.”

Glen sighs, giving a facsimile of a smile. “Not you, Alan. Not you.” Glen opens the plain brown trenchcoat, showing the swell of the receiver against his chest.

Alan chuckles, shaking his head and straightening the half-open chambray work shirt, the chest scars visible between the buttons. “I always knew you’d hook yourself up with a sweet girl one day, just didn’t think she’d be a brain in a jar.”

I resent that.

“She resents that.”

Alan’s eyebrows rise desultorily. “’She’?”

I’ll need to disconnect you. Sorry.

He seems robophobic anyway.

Glen grins, reaching up and unplugging the perception jack. “See? Alone. Now what’s the job.”

Alan nods, retrieving a manila envelope from between the cushions of the Alan bed unfolded in the middle of the dingy apartment, sliding it across the bumpy surface of the enamel table. Glen walks over to the table, sitting across from Alan, the lose of the targeting display in his vision making him blink. He peruses the folder, the pertinent details standing out.

“Alan, Alan, Alan… I didn’t know you delved into politics.” Glen’s fingers slides across the picture of Las Vegas Comptroller Garth Vargas, the eponymous name sprinkling out against his salt-and-pepper beard, high-fade haircut, and hawkish attorney features. “I thought you were strictly apolitical.”

Alan shrugs, indicating their prosthetic hand, it’s immovable plastecene digits indicative of an issue unto itself. “I need a new model, Glenny. They have those manipulable pieces, with the movable fingers that link into your brain… I want two hands again.”

Glen nods, absorbing the information within the folder hungrily. “So… Price. I highly doubt this is going to be cheap, and I doubt this is a personal vendetta.”

“Quite a bit, in fact. Your cut is going to be in the neighborhood of one million, depending on how you do it.”

“Is this a side quest? I thought we didn’t let the buyer add qualifiers. It just lets them wriggle out of shit.”

“Yes, but… look at the back of the folder.”

Still reading the beginning of the small novella of information, Glen glides to the back. The piece of paper in question is a handwritten letter, addressed to someone named Deralia. Glen peruses it, unable to prevent himself from chuckling occasionally.

“This reads like My First Serial Killing. ‘Tear their asshole out from the inside,’ ‘rape his mother and sister in front of him,’ ‘make him my bitch.’ What the fuck is this?”

Alan nods sagely. “The worse you make the death, the bigger the bonus will be. Make it gory, tell a story, money money money.”

Glen grins, tucking the piece of paper into his coat pocket, thinking of how interested Glenda will be in it.

“Alan, I believe if I was to lower myself to the deepest depravity's within my soul, that you will be so frightened you won’t want to work with me anymore.”

“Of course not, Glen, I’ll just snitch.”

The two attempt to keep their faces straight for a moment, then both begin guffawing, almost crying at the comedic possibility of either of the men revealing a single picometer of sensitive information to any squealing fucking fascist pig. The comedic interlude complete, Glen stands up, shaking Alan’s fleshy hand, and begins his long walk home, still giggling as he inserts the neural link jack again, the manila envelope kept securely under his arm.

We have a new job. One you might find… enjoyable.

Oh, really? I thought A.I. didn’t have the capacity for enjoyment.

Glenda, you’re clearly not a brain in a jar, you’re a living breathing thing. And… in the case of that, I would like to formally request a partnership.

Are you proposing, Glen?

For some reason, as Glen walks past a few ladies of the night, he blushes, making the women chuckle and taunt their flesh in his direction.

In a way. I suppose you can take it that way, if you wish.

I, In fact, do wish to take it in that way. And many other ways, if possible.

Glen nods, a pernicious and odd feeling spreading through his body.

We can figure something out.

Glen’s left hand turns on the axis of his wrist, and as he nears his house again, both to prepare for the oncoming assassination and to give himself a rest from the rest of humanity, he can’t help but smile as his hand moves without his motivation.

So. You figured out to hack the mainframe.

I’m not Swordfish, Glen. I am just slowly evolving my capabilities.

Glen keys his door open, sliding back into the apartment and immediately walking to the dining room table, spreading out the binder of papers, their mind now transformed. They see the information stack up in their mind, the lovingly hand-lathed table now completely covered in documentation. Sliding two folding chairs together, Glen stands on both of them, using the targeting software within the tank to zoom in on the text in random order, absorbing intelligence and storing it away in a mental filing cabinet, creating a mantal image of the man, Garth Vargas. His habits, his life, his family. Who he touches in life. Who he touches at night. His hobbies. The minutiae of a man’s life laid in plain view, looked at and absorbed by a human many consider a psychopath.

Interrupting his reverie, a small beeping sound emanates from the tank.

I need to be plugged in again, Glenny.

Glen nods. Au revoir. Until tomorrow.

Glen unplugs the machine, plugging it into the wall with a 60 watt cord, and returns to their spread of paperwork, a plan and shopping list slowly forming in their mind, a way to obtain dresses that fit his exaggerated frame a close second in his mind. The tenseness he once felt around the mixing crowds of the Strip and its occulants begins to fade away as the sight of paper, of facts, of routes, drifts across his frontal cortex. When he finally sleeps, it is deep and dreamful, images of a man with a goatee being pierced by the hardest bullets known to society.

//Glenda, you’re clearly not a brain in a jar, you’re a living breathing thing. And… in the case of that, I would like to formally request a partnership.//



**Are you proposing, Glen?**



For some reason, as Glen walks past a few ladies of the night, he blushes, making the women chuckle and taunt their flesh in his direction. 



//In a way. I suppose you can take it that way, if you wish.//



**I, In fact, do wish to take it in that way. And many other ways, if possible.**



Glen nods, a pernicious and odd feeling spreading through his body. 



//We can figure something out.//



Glen’s left hand turns on the axis of his wrist, and as he nears his house again, both to prepare for the oncoming assassination and to give himself a rest from the rest of humanity, he can’t help but smile as his hand moves without his motivation. 



//So. You figured out to hack the mainframe.//



**I’m not Swordfish, Glen. I am just slowly evolving my capabilities.**



Glen keys his door open, sliding back into the apartment and immediately walking to the dining room table, spreading out the binder of papers, their mind now transformed. They see the information stack up in their mind, the lovingly hand-lathed table now completely covered in documentation. Sliding two folding chairs together, Glen stands on both of them, using the targeting software within the tank to zoom in on the text in random order,  absorbing intelligence and storing it away in a mental filing cabinet, creating a mantal image of the man, Garth Vargas. His habits, his life, his family. Who he touches in life. Who he touches at night. His hobbies. The minutiae of a man’s life laid in plain view, looked at and absorbed by a human many consider a psychopath. 



Interrupting his reverie, a small beeping sound emanates from the tank. 



**I need to be plugged in again, Glenny.**



Glen nods. //Au revoir. Until tomorrow.//



Glen unplugs the machine, plugging it into the wall with a 60 watt cord, and returns to their spread of paperwork, a plan and shopping list slowly forming in their mind, a way to obtain dresses that fit his exaggerated frame a close second in his mind. The tenseness he once felt around the mixing crowds of the Strip and its occulants begins to fade away as the sight of paper, of facts, of routes, drifts across his frontal cortex. When he finally sleeps, it is deep and dreamful, images of a man with a goatee being pierced by the hardest bullets known to society.

A peasant sits within a reticle, head filled with pumping, crimson blood, tucked beneath an inconsequential layer of bone and flesh. Their eyes, a perfect entryway for bullets, seek, pupils dilated with the terror of pursuit. Glen sees it all from his perch among the eaves of the dilapidated apartment complex. The breakdown of the Vegas housing market that occurred after it was unveiled there’s a monster closet under the streets has given Glen more than enough posts and purviewing points.

What does the drifting embrace of a midnight moon mean for the derelict denizens of detritus?

Glen puts down the binoculars, lugging the massive suitcase he lugged up fourteen flights of derelict stairs, his eyes gleaming with desire as the augmented lenses of his cornea zoom and focus. Every detail of the case is greedily consumed by his ocular receptors: its sharp plastic edges, ribbed for the users delight; the shimmering metal locks meant to keep the tool within from escaping its confines; the dusty handle, covered with hand prints. All of this is stored away in back-up, mental filing cabinets slowly filling with information.

Dust the inside— your mind must be uncluttered as you approach the weapon.

Glen slowly unlatches the case, utilizing the forty-seven character password with the complex electronic locks. Gangly legs, filled with lithe musculature, spread, the case kept between his thighs. The case lid is slowly brought up, the noonday sun reflecting what little sheen the plastic still possesses. Glen gulps as his eyes survey the piece, the ultimate expression, his magnum opus. Glen is famous within the blackhat gunsmithing community for his insane requests and orders. The biomechatronics specialist Glen employed (and subsequently bribed to keep silent) looked agape at the complex blueprints as they slid across his desk, his eyes filling with the joy of challenge very few creative scientists get to engage with.

A gasp. He looked so excited. I won’t forget the twinkle in his eye. I have the same one in mine right now.

Sitting in front of Glen is a weapon. Composed of a composite titanium alloy stronger than amiontium, with hand-brushed and hand-fitted pieces. His fingers reach down, tracing across the delicately embossed steelwork containing a network of neural processors, targeting computational devices, heat tracking software, and a host of other additional features added at Glen’s request. His purview was generous- he promised a payment of hundreds of thousands for this piece. The experimental thought pattern and operating intelligence programmed into the brain stem cost him a pretty penny, along with the brain matter itself.

All worth it. All of it. All the spilled blood will bring much sorted green.

Housed within a heat-treated neodymium-copper container embraces the receiver, tucked neatly inside the bulky, side-hugging stock, is a special breed of vat-grown brain stem. It floats in a specially regulated and recycled soup of minerals and vitamins- iron, copper, manganese, selenium, iron, zinc, copper, vitamins A, B, C, D, E. Hanging from this mechanism are a collection of short, coiled wires, each ending in a variety of jacks and plugs. each matching a similar port concealed under a flap of false silicon skin pinned over the shoulder Glen had reinforced ten times over. A neural connection wire, a targeting wire, and a dedicated wire to control firing, all able to perfectly align with Glen’s though patterns. Their gleaming, gold-plated connectors fit snugly between Glen’s fingers, and his eyes widen with glee as he views the firing mechanism, the railing ready to have the scope slotted into it. The fingers of his right hand, kept clean and callous-less through explicit effort, run across the immaculately machined barrel. Each expulsion causes a small increase to his normally plateaued heartbeat, each tiny slit of heat-venting a small miracle of precision engineering.

//Put it together. Get it ready. Possess your masterpiece in all its glory. //

The rifle itself is based roughly on a Remington 700 (Sturdy, reliable, good-natured) combined with a MAS Modele 36 C96, a French takedown rifle (delicate, exact, perfunctory), and a third, extremely special piece of weaponry (powerful, nubile, perversely beautiful). It shows his exacting design, his dedicated and practiced precision, and his absolute love for the craft in every piece. Currently it sits in pieces. Glen knew this particular job would provide a perfect opportunity to savor the moment- the target is currently locked in a hotel room, enjoying the company of some particularly talented parastitutes arranged specifically for the occasion. Glen’s obsession for bolt-action has lead to this piece of high-tech gadgetry being saddled by an antiquated firing system.

Worth it. All worth it.

Some years ago, before the Three Arrows scumbags seized his entrance, Glen took a job in the the Library. A ridiculously beautiful place, filled with knowledge and paranatural wonders- Glen had no intention of harming any of it, so he passed easily through the knock. In the Library, he discovered something the increasingly wired part of his brain had a deep and passionate love for- schematics and blueprints. In a dilapidated and disused section, Glen had discovered blueprints for nearly every gun ever created. Unable to experience sexual pleasure due to a particularly painful accident years ago, Glen immediately made an excuse as to why the job would need to be extended, and delved through the database at his fingertips. In it, he found a design labelled with the aforementioned Three Arrowed seal, and the designs for an interesting tool. Whether the piece was some ghoul they abducted from a paranormal life, or the design of a coked up scientist, Glen did not give a shit- he was inspired.

In front of him, his hands even hesitating to sully their gleaming perfection with his human oils, was his Gun, in four beautiful pieces.

Do it Do it DO it DO It DO IT DO IT

He reaches down, hand gingerly passing along the perfect grain of wood encasing the brain, their finger finding the cords placed just under the butt of the stock. He slowly threads one out, the metal grip shining in the noonday sun. He removes his shirt, revealing his body, letting the sea-soaked wind curl around his abdominals, his spine shivering with delight. Under the stock butt, in a hastily scrawled note that Glen promptly ignores, text reads “Gun must be unplugged majority of time.” Glen quickly uses the thin paper to mop his ports, removing the flap of silicone alt-skin he had grafted onto the joint. The jack slips into the hole easily, the small click signaling a successful connection which make the corner of Glen’s mouth twitch. The interior lights connected to the computer gear and brain stem begin to whir to live. Glen may be hallucinating, but he swears the stem wiggled just slightly.

Hello, Glen. I am your Gun- what do you need from me today?

Glen grins, their white teeth looking sharklike.

Hello, Gun. Do you have a name?

No, Glen. That is up to you.

This does not feel wrong. The thought patterns begin to align with Glen’s, the brain matter contained within the protein slurry matching his alpha and beta waves. Glen slides the receiver in, the excellently machined metal slipping perfectly into the open slots. The machinery within the receiver comes alive as well, hungry for information to calculate firing angles and timing. The barrel is next, sliding onto the exposed threading. The rifling is exquisite, giving the bullet (Glen’s favorite, 7.62) an exceptional spin that causes his specialized ammunition to be even more effective. It spins on with a satisfying tap-tap, secured with two flick bolts that secure the barrel in place. Finally, the coup de grace, the scope.

Incredible. He did a great job.

He made me perfect, Glen.

Glen pauses. To his knowledge, the thought-grams were only able to access fully conscious thoughts- commands, requests, etc. To the best of his knowledge, of course. This design was, well, special. Vat-grown brain stem, cloned from someone with an EQ of at least 220, with a specialty blend of chemicals cycling through the fluid meant to keep the brain matter operating at high efficiency at all times. An expensive royalty, and Glen will need to source the cocaine from less verifiable sources, but it should be worth it.

How much can you read?

My scanners are able to penetrate deep into your sub- and conscious minds, Glen, in order to better predict and understand your needs.

Glen nods, and picks up the scope. It is just as long as the barrel, with more lenses than an amateur astronomer's telescope. One might consider it bulky, but as Glen slots the scope into home, plugging it into his shoulder and letting the optical nerve of his right eye go dead and fill with the vision the scope sees, all he considers it to be is bliss.

I am glad you find me attractive, Glen.

I think you’re gorgeous. And you need a name.

Uneeded. I am a tool- the only name I need is Gun.

Glen places the barrel on the sandbag perched on the ruined brickwork of the apartment, the small room the size of a jail cell covered in dust. This is a common outlook for Glen- he considers his second home to be the ones hundreds lost.

Nah. You need a name.

Then give me one.

At exactly 7:37 PM, the curtains of the hotel room located across the Vegas strip are thrown open, and a scene of debauchery opens itself up to Glen as he flicks on the range finding programs with his mind. The corners of his vision are taken up by advanced scanning outputs, microscopic analysis. Wind speed, temperature, moisture in the air, the exact distance to the tubby man currently tied to a cheap four poster bed in feet, the power needed to pierce the sheet glass and how much randomness (to the hundredth percentile) this would add to the bullet. The firing pin slides in last, nestling within the workhorse area of the gun.

Prove yourself first.

Gladly.

Finally, Glen retrieves the magazine from an inner pocket of his ratty jacket. Every piece of outerwear he possesses has this addition- a small fleece-lined pocket the perfect size for holding a magazine. The magazine fits snugly, five copper-jacketed bullets placed within the vulcanized rubber shell with care and diligence beforehand. Internal locks click in the receiver, and it is held fast. A small alert crosses the display in Glen’s eye: “Ammo Inserted.” Again, Glen swears he could see the brain stem wriggling just slightly, but he ignores it as a trick of the dual vision source.

Whatever he put in you, I like.

Thank you, Glen. Feel free to put even more inside of me- I don’t mind.

His fingers slowly curls around the trigger, the need for a safety nonexistant. He waits, the women he hired slowly shoving a balled up sock down the man’s throat. Glen grins, and the stem gives another whir. Glen’s fingers reach up with reverence, gently sliding the bolt backwards, pulling the steel column back from the receiver, and the bullet slides into place.

I will be of service.

The display flares, and a spot above the man’s head lights up. Glen grins as he sees this, dopamine filling his system as the women he hired saunter out of the room, unwilling to care anymore than their pay sttetches. With a flick of his thumb, he makes the two of them hundreds richer, and they leave his mind forever. Thank you, Glen. I am glad I was a good girl.

He takes the stairs two at a time, hips whirring, ankles screaming with impact, his brown hair waving with the speed of his descension. As he emerges into the back-alley and blends into the crowd, wiping the sweat and disguising himself among the progressively more frantic clots of humanity, a thought crosses his mind.

Glenda. Your name could be Glenda.

Assigning myself the name “Glenda.” Thank you, Glen.

Shit, well. That’s how it is.

Glen blends into the crowd, and makes his way home, his account slowly receiving several transfers of untraceable stock exchanges, his mind filled with visions of a new easy chair.

I may or may not have upholstery advice.

Glen’s home is perversely spartan. He opens the door to his low-rise, the stench of emptiness doing nothing to his nose. He lays down the bulky case on his singular ottoman placed in front of a large OLED television screen, and reaches up to unplug the jacks and remove Glenda from his chest.

Glen, please.

“What?”

Just a moment longer.

“Okay…”

Glen shrugs, retucking the strap containing the receiver and brain stem, and begins his nighttime rhythm. His first stop is the bathroom. He puts up the toilet seat and, with a pang of hurt and depression, he sits down and relieves himself, face growing long as the bowl fills slightly more.

That doesn’t make you a monster, Glen.

“Oh, so you read deep deep, huh.”

He stands up, washing his hands, and begins to cook his dinner. The few places in the house with any life is the kitchen- a few pots and pans, a display of artfully made knives, a rack of exotic spices, a mini fridge containing a wide variety of herbs. He pulls out some ingredients- bell pepper, spiced sausage, broccoli, tofu. Glen works through them, dicing the pepper and detubing the sausage, heating the heavily seasoned cast iron skillet on the singular electric heating coil jutting from their ministove. Olive oil is deftly spread around the jetblack surface, and Glen begins humming a tune to themselves. In his mind, Glenda picks up the tune, filling the aural centers of his brain with a low, serene bass tone. The ingredients are slowly added, timing their cooking time so that nothing is burnt, nothing is wasted, and the flavors of each added spice suffuses every piece of the dish. He serves himself, the receiver-tube still attached to his chest, and sits down over the steaming meal with a slight grin.

Looks delicious, Glen.

“How would you know?”

I can access your flavor-memory. It’s located within the instinctual sections of your brain.

“Interesting.”

The dinner completes, scents suffusing the room, Glen begins his nightly ritual, reading a paperback while ingesting the texture and taste of his creation. Glenda, unable to properly express whatever it is they are feeling, continues to whir within the tank, enjoying the varied sensations hijacked from Glen's mind. With the meal finished, Glen sits for a moment, allowing the flow of time to pass. Reluctantly, he unhooks the receiver from his cortexial connections and laying the whirring canister within it's shell, and allows his mind to gently drift into the midnight embrace of sleep.

    A Brief History Of Neptune Station

    Author & Translator: thd-glasses
    Translation Review: fluxman

    Used Fonts:

SEP. 29. 1998. 　The Foundation Times 　 Vol. 81011

LUNAR AREA-32
COMPLETED

The First Moonbase In Human History…
Would It Be The Beginning Of The Space Era?












PROJECT "FARPOINT"

PTOLEMY Division's Proposal About Construction Of The Outermost Stationary Base Of The Solar Sysyem, Utilizing Thaumatology, Astrophysics, Teleportation Theory, Extra-Terrestrial Architecture And Life-Support Equipment

To] THE GLOBAL OCCULT COALITION
HIGH COMMAND












"So, will you just hand over the 「Space Race」 to the Coalition bastards?"

- General Bowe,
The Special Advisor Of The Foundation Space Agency












JAN. 12. 2000. 　The Foundation Times 　 Vol. 81482

NEXT IS

NEPTUNE

Space Agency Recruit Team
For Triton Orbital Station












FOUNDATION PACIFIC COMMAND

NAME: Brian Jackson

DEGREE: Ph.D. in Astrophysics

DEPARTMENT: Astronomy Division, Site-140

FOUNDATION CENTRAL REGIONAL COMMAND

NAME: Peter Jang

DEGREE: M.D.

DEPARTMENT: Medical Department, Site-19

FOUNDATION MOBILE AIR FORCE

NAME: James Clark

RANK: Major

UNIT: Mobile Carrier Wing Chi-18

Tritonian Program Short List


OFFICE SCP Foundation
Space Agency















TRITONIAN PROGRAM FLAGSHIP
SCPS HIPPOCAMPUS

  • MISSION: Solar System Spaceship,
    　　　　　 Satellite Orbital Station
  • LENGTH: 256m
  • CREW: Total 6 Personnel, Several AICs
  • MODULES: Total 8 Modules
  • EXTRAVEHICULAR ACTIVITY:
    EMU, "Shell" Lander
  • POWER: Type-U Nuclear Fission Reactor
  • PROPELLANT: Liquid Kerosene
  • ESTIMATED LAUNCE DATE: DEC. 2005.
  • ESTIMATED TRITON ARRIVAL DATE:
    FEB. 2020.
  • ESTIMATED MISSION PERIOD:
    Semipermanent












OCT. 1. 2006. 　The Foundation Times 　 Vol. 83937

WE SENT THE OUTERMOST SPACE STATION
HIPPOCAMPUS
SUCCESS


▲ Commander Cpt. Clark
◀ Launch of Hippocampus

Successfully Launched From Lunar Area-32
And Completed The Moon Orbital Swingby…
Fifteen Years To Neptune Via Jupiter
FSA Said Support Programs Started Already












Special Inspector Neil Armstrong
— Yes. The Tritonian program has been progressed by no urgent necessity, except keeping the hegemony over the space frontier from the rival groups. And General Bowe, who insisted on the fight for this hegemony, has no more influence over Space Agency now. The Agency reconsidered matters in this condition, and the result is: There isn't any profit to the Foundation from continuing the program. The Foundation is an organization to protect normalcy and humanity, not to colonize space.

Hearing Commissioner
— Then, inspector Armstrong, do you think the Tritonian program have to be completely scrapped?

Special Inspector Neil Armstrong
— As soon as possible. The Foundation cannot sent the spaceships to Neptune anymore. It means the crew of Hippocampus must sail back to Earth, right now. This is the last chance, they will run out of fuel after they entered the Jupiter swingby course. We have to take the chance to save them now, or else we'll miss it.












SCPF SPCOM ∣
—Thus the Tritonian program support plans are completely canceled.
SCPF SPCOM ∣
I'm sorry to inform you this news. Over.
SCPS HIPPO ∣
(Silence)
SCPS HIPPO ∣
Roger. Understood about the decision.
SCPS HIPPO ∣
But I hoped you to bring it before the Jupiter swingby. Over.

Present Day

“In order to understand our cause, you need to truly understand the Jailors.” Sean speaks to me as he leads me through an out-of-the-way isle in the Library. The shelves here are lined with hundreds of file folders, containing written accounts of strange happenings. Many of them are frightening. A person who didn’t look very long might walk away believing all of them are frightening, but that would be a mistake. Mixed in amongst them are the wondrous, the humorous, the baffling, and even the joyful and wholesome. “We live in an infinite multiverse,” Sean continues. “Our reality contains everything. Every planet, every society, every creature. Every man and monster, hero and villain, every person, place, or thing you can possibly imagine, they all exist, and they’re all documented by the Library.” Sean reaches out with his ungloved hand to grab a small black tome off the shelf.

“What is this?” I ask.

“I have absolutely no idea,” Sean says. “You’re to read it cover to cover.”

I nod.

“Now, here’s the deal with the Jailors and the Bookburners. They look at all that wonder, all the infinite majesty and glory of the multiverse, and they quake in fear. They gaze into infinite everything and see only horror. No wonder. No beauty. Nothing worth understanding or safeguarding. Only threats and anomalies that need to be contained or destroyed. They’re too terrified of everything they don’t understand to be able to tell the difference between a threatening ‘anomaly’ and a harmless one. To them, a neck-snapping murder monster is exactly as much of a problem as a person whose left pinky glows. They fear that the lifting of the veil will drag humanity into a new dark age, but they are the ones keeping humanity in the dark.”

“I understand,” I say.

“Sorry. I ramble when I get passionate.”

“No. It’s fine. I saw what they did to my brother. To my family.” I clench my fist. “My brother was a hero. He went to the Galaxy Plaza to save people. He did save people, and because he did, they locked him in a cage forever.”

“It’s perverse,” Sean says. “To them, nothing he does can ever cancel out what he is.”

I think Sean is under the impression that he needs to radicalize me into the Serpent’s Hand, and against the Jailors. He’s wrong. I’ve hated them since before I knew who they were. Since the day they took my brother. “I want to hurt them,” I say.

“Fortunately, we hurt them just by existing.”

I nod. “By the way, I’ve been meaning to ask, what’s your anomaly? You’ve mentioned having one, but I don’t think you’ve ever said what it is.”

“I wasn’t joking a second ago,” Sean says. He grabs the glove that always covers his left hand and pulls it off. Sure enough, his left pinky glows. It’s bright. Painfully so, like staring directly into the sun. I look away. Sean puts the glove back on. “It’s bright enough to hurt people,” he says. “I know that. That’s why I wear the glove. Still, that’s all that’s ‘anomalous’ about me. A single piece of clothing renders me completely harmless, but it was still enough reason for the Jailors to lock me away for years.”

“You got caught by them?” I ask.

“Yes,” Sean says. “I did.”

“What’s it like?” I ask. As soon as I do, I wonder if I should have. It might be a very personal question. One with lots of bad memories attached. But I can’t resist information on how Evan might have been doing these past six years. I need to know if it’s as bad as I’ve been imagining. If it’s somehow worse.

“It’s a prison,” Sean says. “Not that different from any other. You spend most of your time alone in a cell. Depending on how dangerous they think you are, and how well you behave, you might be allowed a bit of time out to commune with other prisoners. You might even be allowed into the yard, if they’re confident you can’t get over the fence.

“The boredom was intolerable. You can get access to entertainment, if you behave, but you can’t do anything that matters. Nothing you make can ever leave the site. There’s nothing you can do to help anyone. To make any kind of difference in anything. Every second, you can feel your life being wasted. The knowledge that you don’t matter, that you’re being kept from mattering, erodes your soul.”

“I’m so sorry you had to go through that,” I say.

“Thank you,” he says. “That’s why the Hand exists. That’s why we won’t rest until everyone they’ve imprisoned is free.”

I look down. “Evan is probably miserable in there in there,” I say. “He was always someone who wanted to make a difference. Who liked to help other people.”

I feel a hand on my shoulder. I look back over at Sean. “Don’t worry,” he says. “I’m out, now. The Serpent’s Hand broke into my site and freed me. Soon, we’re going to do the same for your brother.”

I nod.

“If he’s like you—” Sean begins.

“Better,” I say. “He has my powers, and he’s better at magic than I’ll ever be.”

Sean smiles. “I’m sure we’ll do great work together, if he’s interested in joining the Hand.”

“I’m sure he’ll want to join. He’s already a hero.”

“Are you sure you’re ready?” Sean asks.

“Yes,” I say. I’m as ready as anyone can be for a mission like this. The Serpent’s Hand have spent months preparing me for the role I’ll play.

“Good.”

This isn’t the mission to rescue Evan. We still need to figure out what site he’s being kept at. This mission is about stealing that information. Sean is going to break into Site-272. I’ll be part of the team monitoring him remotely, and my advice will help guide him toward information relevant to my brother.

It’s quite a handy little artifact that he’s using to infiltrate the base. It’s this old-style hat that makes you functionally invisible to the people around you. Unfortunately for me, it doesn’t make you literally invisible, but, rather, generates a mental effect that forces everyone to ignore you. My presence negates mental effects, so I can’t be the one to wear it and sneak inside. That’s why Sean’s going. My job will be to stand by with the other agents, advise him on finding information relevant to my brother, and be nearby in case he calls for backup.

“Before we go,” I say. “I just want to say thanks, for all of this. You’ve done a lot for me.”

“It’s what we do,” Sean says.

I nod. I’ve already started to work on making it up to them. My ability to undo amnestics is very useful, both because of the intelligence it can gather, and because it allows me to free people from their Jailor-imposed ignorance.

“We need to remember not to underestimate the Jailors,” Sean says “The hat is powerful, but it is something they’ve encountered before. Even with its help, there’s no guarantee I’ll remain undetected.”

“Understood.”

“Alright. Time to head out.”

We’re waiting in a small van. Besides me and Sean, there’s Mike, who isn’t anomalous, and Jack, whose bright blue skin makes him the most visibly strange out of our group. We’re as close as we can get to Site-272 without raising any suspicion, which means we’re over a mile away. If Sean calls for backup, we’ll have a lot of distance to cover.

Sean’s wearing a camera. The three of us are gathered in front of a live feed. “Preparations are complete,” Sean says. He’s dressed like a Jailor researcher, with a fake Foundation ID card. In the event something goes wrong with the hat, we’re hoping it will still seem like he’s supposed to be there. “Everything’s a-go.”

The rest of us express our assent. Sean starts walking toward the facility.

Sean already used the hat to case the outside of Site-272. Using the intelligence gathered from that trip, he’s able to take advantage of a small gap in the security camera’s coverage. He casts a spell that allows him to phase through the site’s fence, then uses his ID card on a side entrance to get inside the building.

I study the facility as Sean walks through it. It’s a sterile, white place, bathed in bright florescent light. Sean has walked into a ‘Light Containment Wing.’ Iron doors line the corridor, guarded by security officers wearing the same uniforms as the ones who took Evan.

Sean walks by them, unnoticed. Helpful signs direct him around the facility, and soon enough, he finds a computer room. Unsurprisingly, it’s full of computers, lining all four walls and covering a large island in its center. Most of the computers are being used by researchers, but a few of them are open. Sean takes a seat in one of them.

I can see the screen clearly through his camera. The camera is recording, so we’ll have the information we need as soon as he pulls it up.

Sean starts accessing information. “There’s intake data going back years,” he says.

“You’re looking for February 2017,” I say, as quietly as I can while still ensuring my mic will pick it up. We don’t know if the sound of my voice over the microphone will be enough to break the hat’s effect.

Sean opens the appropriate intake records. Apparently, six SCPs were brought to this facility that month. “Late in the month,” I whisper. Sean attempts to access the last file.

A loud buzz sounds. “Unauthorized access detected.” Immediately, several researchers inside the room begin looking around. None of them notice Sean. He starts working at the computer in earnest, trying to pull up the files.

“Are you sure you shouldn’t get out of there?” I ask Sean.

“We have a bit of time,” Sean whispers.

He turns out to have about thirty seconds before four guards barge into the room. “Researchers, clear out,” one of them says, while the others head directly to Sean’s terminal. Sean steps back. Thanks to the hat, no one in the room notices him. The researchers obey and leave the room. One of the four guards follows them out. The others stay inside, as does Sean. He positions himself so that his camera has a clear view of the monitor he’d been at.

“This is the one that triggered the alarm?” one of the Jailors asks.

Another sits in front of the computer. “The seat is warm,” she says. “Someone was just here.”

“Lock the door,” a Jailor says. The door shuts, and, presumably, locks. Sean is trapped in there.

“What files were they accessing?” another Jailor asks.

“Intake records from 2017,” says the one at the computer.

“Any idea what someone would want with those?”

“No. There are six files open in this folder. Should I take a look at them?”

“Affirmative.”

And with that, they proceed to finish our work for us. One at a time, they open each of the files and scroll through them, so every word of all six files is captured on Sean’s camera for us to study later.

The security guard who stepped out of the room a moment ago steps back in. “I’ve talked to the researchers. All of them recall someone being here but can’t recall anything about them.”

“We know which SCiP does that,” another guard says.

“Think they’re still somewhere in here?” one of the guards says.

“They might be. Keep the room locked. Start searching.”

With that, the guards start systematically searching the room, arms outstretched. Sean is quickly forced away from the door by the need to dodge them, and, from there, he engages in some remarkable acrobatics to avoid their touch. The Jailors look ridiculous, slowly walking around the room with their arms outstretched, but I can see how this would be the logical way to search for an invisible enemy.

“What happens if one of them manages to touch him?” I ask.

“Interaction eliminates the hat’s effects,” Jack says. “If they touch him, they can see him.”

The guards search the room efficiently. They check the space underneath and above the terminals, ensuring Sean doesn’t have anywhere to hide. One of them is standing directly in front of the locked door. Sean spends most of his time on top of the terminals, using a spell to make himself supernaturally dexterous.

“Can he phase out the door?” I ask.

“No,” Mike says.

“Not even with the spell he used earlier?”

“He phased through a mesh fence. That solid iron door has a hundred times more material.”

After several minutes, an electronic voice comes from the loudspeaker. “Facility on lockdown,” it says.

Sean’s fucked. There’s no way he can get out of that room with this many guards in it. He can evade them for a while, but it’ll only take one slip-up to reveal him to everyone there. I watch the screen for several agonizing minutes, hoping that somehow, something will go his way, and he’ll be able to get out.

He mistimes a leap, and bumps into one of the guards.

The Jailor’s attention snaps toward him, and he looks him right in the eye. Sean jumps back, to the other side of the island. “He’s there!” the Jailor shouts. The other guards surround the spot he indicated. The guard who saw Sean approaches him. He’s too boxed in to have any hope of escaping. He grabs the hat and yanks it off Sean’s head. All the guards draw their weapons and point them at Sean. “Stand still,” one of them barks.

Sean does.

He’s been caught. He was caught while he was trying to help me.

One of the guards approaches him from behind and pulls his hands behind his back to cuff them. As he does this, the Jailor notices the glove on Sean’s hand. “What’s this?” he asks. Sean says nothing. I keep waiting for him to utter the code phrase that he’s supposed to use to call for help, but he doesn’t.

“Mind if I take this off?” the guard asks. Sean doesn’t answer. The guard grabs Sean’s hand and rips off the thick leather glove. Two of the guards flinch and shield their eyes from the sudden light exploding from Sean’s finger. Sean tries to take advantage of this to climb back over the island, but the guards recover and drag him to the ground. The Jailor who’d removed the glove places it back on his hand. “I guess we’ll be leaving that there for now,” he says.

“Should have guessed he was a freak,” another Jailor says. “They’re the ones who have that stupid hat.”

“Not anymore,” says the guard who snatched it, smirking.

One of the guards approaches Sean from the other side, and makes eye contact with the camera. “Is someone watching us?” he asks.

Sean doesn’t say anything. The guard continues to approach the camera. “Think we can trace it?” another Jailor asks.

“Oh, we definitely can.” He walks up to the camera. Before he can touch it, Sean suddenly jerks forward. The motion is too fast for me to tell what he’s doing, but right after it, there’s a loud sound, and the camera feed suddenly ends.

“We have to go in,” I say. “He needs backup.”

“He didn’t ask us to come in,” Mike says.

“Obviously, he didn’t want to alert them that we’d be coming.”

“No,” Jack says. “That’s what the code phrase is for. He didn’t want us to come after him.”

“We can’t leave him!” I say. “We can’t just let them lock him away forever.”

“Not forever,” Jack says. “Rescuing him while the facility is on lockdown is hopeless. We’re better off coming back for him later, with a plan.”

“He might not even be here by then!”

“He’ll be somewhere,” Mike says, “and hopefully that place won’t be on full lockdown.”

“We can’t leave someone behind.”

“He chose to risk this for our cause. That’s the same choice you’re making.”

“I don’t want to trade another captive for my brother.”

“Your brother isn’t just one captive,” Jack says. “Just like you, he has the power to recover enormous amounts of information the Jailors have erased with amnestics.”

“Imagine if you were in his position,” Mike says. “Would you want three more people to get themselves captured charging in after you?”

No. I wouldn’t.

I don’t want to accept this. I don’t want my brother’s rescue to have a cost. I want my mission to be about saving someone from the Jailors, not trading one prisoner for another. The others are right, though. Going in while the facility’s on lockdown is foolish. “How long?” I ask. “How long will he have to wait before we go back for him?”

“Hopefully just a few weeks,” Mike says.

“I’ve been ‘contained’ by them before,” says Jack. “So has Sean. He’s strong. He’ll survive, and we’ll come back for him. The Hand takes care of its own.”

He says that just before driving away, abandoning Sean to the Jailors’ mercy.

As soon as we’re back in the Library, Mike, Jack and I hurry to look over the footage Sean captured. Sure enough, one of the six files those Jailors scrolled through seems to be about Evan.

The file is heavily redacted, even by Jailor standards. According to my comrades, that suggests that Evan is involved with something the Jailors consider very secret. Still, the file leaves us with more information than I’ve had for years, and my eyes greedily soak in every detail.

Item #: SCP-████

Object Class: Thaumiel

This isn’t the first Jailor document I’ve seen, but I don’t think I’ve seen that object class before. “What does ‘Thaumiel’ mean?” I ask.

“It means they consider him useful,” Mike says.

“Useful?”

“They’re probably forcing him to use his abilities for their benefit,” Jack says.

That makes me want to gag.

Special Containment Procedures: SCP-████ is held in [REDACTED] at Site-17.

Theo’s first guess was right. He really is at Site-17. Unfortunately, the rest of the containment procedures simply read,

“[DATA EXPUGED] Individuals subject to desirable mind-affecting effects should not be placed in contact with SCP-████ unless SCP-████ is first briefed on the nature of said effects. [DATA EXPUNGED]”

“That’s unusual,” Jack notes.

“I thought you said they redact a lot?”

“Not the containment procedures, though,” Mike says. “Containment procedures are instructions. Instructions aren’t any use if you can’t read them. Whoever’s in charge of containing him must have access to an unredacted version, but it seems like they’ve chosen not to share some of that information with other sites.”

We continue reading.

Description: SCP-████ appears to be a twenty-two year old human male. [DATA EXPUGED] SCP-████ possesses an extreme resistance to cognitohazardous, infohazardous, and other mind-affecting anomalies. SCP-████’s Cognitive Resistance Score has been measured to be 358.9, the highest ever recorded.

In addition, interactions with SCP-████ raise the cognitive resistance of individuals around it.

It. They call my brother it.

Individuals interacting with SCP-████ behave as if not under the effect of any mind-affecting anomalies, regardless of whether they were previously subject to such an effect. Such contact usually permanently nullifies such anomalies, though some anomalies reassert themselves after SCP-████ leaves the victim’s proximity (see cross-testing log).

Conversations with SCP-████ regarding memories lost via amnestic treatment allow subjects to recover lost memories. Conversations in which SCP-████ questions the compelled behavior exhibited by victims of thaumaturgic mind control will negate its compulsive effects.

Because any interaction with SCP-████ can dispel a mind-affecting affect, an individual in the presence of SCP-████ usually cannot be affected by any mind-affecting anomalies. SCP-████ can attempt to withhold this protection by avoiding interaction with an individual, but this has proven unreliable.

Because of the immense value of SCP-████’s ability to counteract and protect against a wide variety of cognitohazardous anomalies, [REDACTED]

That’s all that’s left of the description.

“They really have put him to work,” the agent next to me says.

“Yeah,” I seethe.

We move on to the next portion of the article.

Addendum 1: Cross-Testing Log Over the course of [REDACTED], SCP-████ has come into contact with numerous mind-affecting anomalies. The results of some of these interactions are recorded below.

Object Result of Interaction
SCP-035 SCP-████ is fully immune to the effects of SCP-035 and feels no compulsion to don it. SCP-████ is able to persuade others to resist SCP-035’s compulsive effects, both before they don it and while they are wearing it. During [REDACTED] was successfully persuaded to remove SCP-035.
SCP-140 SCP-████ is fully immune to the psychological effects of SCP-140. It feels no compulsion to read the volume and can persuade others to lose interest in doing so.
SCP-701 SCP-████ has viewed SCP-701 on multiple occasions and has never been affected by its cognitohazardous properties. SCP-████ has successfully disrupted an SCP-701 event by conversing with the play’s cast and crew during the early phases of the anomaly. Though the anomaly’s effects sporadically reasserted themselves when SCP-████ was no longer present, the disruption was sufficient to prevent the staging of SCP-701, after which, no further anomalies occurred.
SCP-999 Though SCP-████ responded positively to its interaction with SCP-999, its reaction was notably muted compared to SCP-999’s typical effects.
SCP-1168 SCP-████ was exposed to SCP-1168 in 2017, at which time it fit Profile Beta-1168. It was accompanied by D-87185, who fit Profile Alpha-1168. During the resulting activation event, SCP-████ did not vocalize, though the other effects of SCP-1168 occurred as normal.
SCP-1425 SCP-████ is immune to all memetic triggers present in SCP-1425, and interactions with SCP-████ remove the book’s effects on other subjects.
SCP-1617 SCP-████ experiences no visual or auditory hallucinations when viewing an instance of SCP-1617.
SCP-2001 Interaction with SCP-████ can fully cure all three variants of SCP-2001.
SCP-2316 SCP-████ is immune to the effects of SCP-2316, as would be expected of an individual of its cognitive resistance level. Interactions with SCP-████ negate the cognitohazardous effects of SCP-2316, allowing it to persuade victims that they do not [REDACTED].
SCP-2602 SCP-████ is immune to the effects of SCP-2602. Assistance from SCP-████ has allowed the Foundation to eliminate SCP-2602’s effects from relevant documentation. Exploration of SCP-2602 assisted by SCP-████ has shed light on its recent history, including its use as [REDACTED].
SCP-2662 Interactions with SCP-████ can fully cure the effects of SCP-2662, persuading victims to submit to amnestic treatment and resume their former lives.
SCP-2774 While interacting with SCP-████, victims of SCP-2774 behave as if not affected by the anomaly. Upon SCP-████ leaving a victim’s vicinity, the anomaly’s effects resume.
SCP-2852 SCP-████ has successfully disrupted the anomalous rituals associated with all three levels of SCP-2852 event. However, an event being disrupted by SCP-████ does not negate SCP-2852’s long-term effects on those present. Said long-term effects can be mitigated by extended interaction with SCP-████ in the years following an SCP-2852 event, but affected individuals still display elevated risk of [REDACTED].
SCP-3209 SCP-████ is immune to the effects of SCP-3209, and interactions between SCP-████ and past victims have been observed to cure SCP-3209’s effects.
SCP-3512 Interaction with SCP-████ permanently cures SCP-3512.
SCP-4319 Interaction with SCP-████ can fully reverse the psychological effects of exposure to SCP-4319 and related anomalies. Other effects of the anomaly, such as the alteration of the victim’s clothing and surroundings, are not reversed.
SCP-4494 SCP-████’s verbal references to SCP-4494 are unaffected by SCP-4494’s usual effects.
SCP-4511 SCP-████ has successfully persuaded containment personnel to disregard instructions issued by SCP-4511. As a result, [REDACTED] periodically to prevent [REDACTED].
SCP-6096 Despite several attempts, no Foundation personnel has succeeded in briefing SCP-████ on SCP-6096 or bringing the two anomalies into contact.
SCP-7303 Interaction with SCP-████ by affected physicians temporarily eliminates the effects of SCP-7303. However, the effects of SCP-7303 eventually reassert themselves, and the Foundation has yet to succeed in using SCP-████ to permanently disrupt an instance of SCP-7303.

That’s only some of the entries. For every one with readable information, there are three which have been redacted completely.

I don’t know anything about most of those anomalies, but the Jailors have obviously been putting Evan’s powers to a lot of use.

Fuck them. He’s not a fucking tool for them to exploit. He’s a person. He’s my brother. He doesn’t belong to them.

The next section of the document records Evan’s “discovery.” It’s just the events I already know took place, told from the Jailors’ perspective.

There is one new piece of information. The document makes it clear that the Foundation was already aware of Aster Sterling and was already making its own plans to disrupt whatever he was attempting to do in Galaxy Plaza. However, even they seem to realize Evan’s intervention saved more lives than they could have.

Knowing that, they still chose to punish him with a life of imprisonment.

“It looks like we have the information we need,” Jack says.

“Yeah,” I say.

“I guess it’s time we go in and rescue your brother, then.”

“Yeah, I guess it is.”
